content.html:
Matthew had a problem. His Aunt Tina was visiting that afternoon, and he had nothing for her to eat!

“I could buy some cake!” Matthew thought. He had passed a bakery earlier that day which had a very yummy-looking coconut cake in the window. That would be perfect!

explanation.html:
The cake is divided into 10 equal pieces, so the denominator is 10.

3 of those pieces have mangoes, so the numerator is 3.

Therefore, the fraction we want is 3/10.

feedback.html: Correct! You're ready to learn more!

Oops, read the question carefully!

6/10 is the fraction of the cake that has any kind of fruits on it. But that's not what Mr. Baker is asking for.

Oops, read the question carefully!

12/21 is the fraction of fruits on the cake that are mangoes. But that's not what Mr. Baker is asking for. (He's talking about the fraction of the cake, not the fraction of the total number of fruits.)

Oops, read the question carefully!

4/10 is the fraction of the cake that has nothing on it. But that's not what Mr. Baker is asking for.

Oops, it looks like you've forgotten how to write a fraction!

Let's take a moment to learn that again properly. You'll need it later!

Oops, read the question carefully!

3/6 is the fraction of cake slices that have mangoes, out of all the slices that have fruits on them.

But that's not what Mr. Baker is asking for. He's talking about the fraction of the whole cake -- not just the part of the cake that has fruits on it. Try again?
No, that's not right. You've got the denominator correct, but you need to count the number of selected pieces carefully. Try again.
No, that's not right. It looks like you didn't count the number of pieces of cake correctly? The denominator of your fraction is not correct.

hint_content.html: Start by finding the denominator. The denominator is the total number of equal parts that the whole cake is divided into.

Next, find the numerator by counting the number of selected parts.

In this case, it's the number of parts that have mangoes (the orange pieces) on them. Make sure to count carefully!

Always be careful about what you're counting. The question will have clues!

Here, we're looking at a fraction of the cake. So, we should be counting pieces of the cake, not the individual fruits.

content.html:
“Very good, Matthew,” said Mr. Baker. “Now, it’s important to be careful that you understand exactly what is being asked for when you're asked to give a fraction."

"Here's a cake I made recently. What fraction of the cake has mangoes on it?" (The mangoes are the orange pieces, by the way!)

explanation.html:
There are 4 pieces with dhal on them, so the numerator is 4. (We don't care about the pieces which are burnt, since the question is only about the pieces with dhal on them.)

There are 6 pieces of roti in total, so the denominator is 6.

Therefore, the answer is 4/6.

feedback.html: Yes, well done!
No, that's the fraction of the roti that was burnt. But that's not the fraction that Mr. Baker is asking for. Try again!

You've got the denominator correct, but the numerator is wrong. Make sure to correctly count the number of pieces with dhal on them.

Try again!
No, try again. You can do this!

hint_content.html:
Remember that a fraction has a numerator and a denominator. It is written as

         Numerator / Denominator

The denominator is the total number of equal pieces that the roti is divided into. Can you figure that out?
The roti is divided into 6 pieces, so the denominator is 6.

This means that the answer is:

      something / 6

The numerator is the number of selected pieces. In this case, it's the number of pieces with dhal on them. (We don't care about the pieces which are burnt, since the question only asks about the pieces with dhal on them.)
There are 4 pieces with dhal on them, so the numerator is 4.

content.html:
"No, that's not right," said Mr. Baker. "But let's try again."

"What fraction of the roti below has dhal on it?”

Meet Matthew!

Matthew is a young man who likes friends, sports, and eating cake! He also likes learning new things. We’ll follow Matthew as he learns about fractions and how to use them.

You should know the following before going on:

  • The counting numbers (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ….)
  • How to tell whether one counting number is bigger or smaller than another

You should also get some paper and a pen or pencil to write with, and find a quiet place to work. Take your time, and go through the story at your own pace. Understanding is more important than speed!

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

Taking his coconut cake with him, Matthew triumphantly headed home to Aunt Tina. He was already planning to have friends over the next afternoon, so he knew he’d be back to the bakery for more goodies soon!

Before leaving the bakery, Matthew wrote down some important notes in his notebook. You might want to write them down so you remember too!

  • Fractions describe parts of a whole. They can be written using a slash or a horizontal bar, e.g. 2/3 or 2|3 (horizontal bar).
  • The first number is called the numerator. It is the number of selected pieces.
  • The second number is called the denominator. It is the total number of equal pieces that the whole is divided into.

feedback.html: Correct! You're ready for the next step.
No, that's not right. Review the information and try again.

hint_content.html:
When you divide something into five equal parts, each part is called a fifth.



How many fifths are in the last picture that Mr. Baker drew?

content.html:
Matthew looked confused. "What's a fraction?" he asked.

"Ah," said Mr. Baker. "That just means how much of the whole thing you want.” He picked up a napkin and a pencil. “Look,” he said, starting to draw.

“Here’s a cake. Pretend it’s divided into five equal parts, OK? Since there are five equal parts, each part is called a fifth.”

Then he picked up a colored pencil and colored in one of the parts.

“Now look, Matthew. If I asked you how many parts of the cake were colored red, we could say one fifth. Because one of the fifths is colored in.”

Then he colored in another piece.

“And now we could say that two fifths of the cake are red. Both ‘one fifth’ and ‘two fifths’ are fractions, because they tell us how much of a whole thing we’re talking about.

“Now here’s an easy question for you, Matthew,” said Mr. Baker, coloring another part of the cake. “How many fifths are colored red now?”

“Yes, that’s right!” said Mr. Baker.

"The whole cake is divided into seven equal pieces, so the second number is 7. Two of the pieces are shaded, so the first number is 2."

"Got it!" said Matthew.

As Matthew entered the bakery, a kind-looking man looked up from the counter and smiled at him.

"Hello!" he said. "My name’s Mr. Baker. What would you like today?"

"The coconut cake in the window!" Matthew answered.

“The whole cake?" asked Mr. Baker.

"Ummmm.... no," said Matthew. He knew how to ask for one, or two, or three cakes. But he didn’t want the whole cake. He just wanted part of it.

“You know,” Mr. Baker said kindly. “I can cut a small piece for you, if you like. Just tell me how much. What fraction of the cake would you like?”

feedback.html: You got it!
No, that's not right. Look at the explanation again, and give it another try.

hint_content.html: What is the total number of equal parts that the whole cake is divided into? That should be the second number in the fraction.

The whole cake has 7 equal pieces, so 7 is the second number in the fraction.

So, the fraction must be: . Can you figure out the first number?

content.html:
“That’s correct!" said Mr. Baker. "You see, a fraction tells us two things: how many equal parts something is divided into all together, and how many of those parts we want.

"It’s quicker to use numbers rather than words to write fractions, so instead of writing 'three sixths' we can write '3/6' or . First, we write the number of parts we want, then we write the total number of parts."

"Now, take a look at this cake."

"Which of these fractions describes the darker part of the cake?"

Congratulations on completing this lesson! We hope you found it to be … a piece of cake!

Matthew had learned from Mr. Baker what a fraction was. But there was one thing he wondered about: why did Mr. Baker keep talking about "equal parts", not just "parts"? Was it important that the parts were equal?

To find out, take a look at the next lesson, where Matthew meets Crumb, the Assistant Baker, for the first time!

feedback.html: That's correct!
No, that's the fraction of the roti that was burnt. But that's not the fraction that Mr. Baker is asking for...

No, that's not right. Remember: The numerator is always the first or top number, the number of pieces we want. The denominator is always the second or bottom number, the total number of pieces the whole is divided into. Go ahead and give it another try.

content.html:
“You’ve learned a lot about fractions, Matthew!” said Mr. Baker. “Now, if you answer just one more question correctly on the first try, I’ll give you the coconut cake you wanted for free!”

“Here is a roti that my assistant, Crumb, burnt badly. He isn’t very honest, unfortunately, so he tried to cover some of the burnt places with dhal. He got dhal on some of the other pieces, too. What fraction of the roti has dhal on it?”

feedback.html: Correct, well done! That was a hard one!
No, that's not right. Let's give it another go.

content.html:
“Don’t worry, Matthew,” said Mr. Baker. “That one was a bit tricky. But maybe you can get this one right on the first try!”

He took the coconut cake from the window. Some pieces had cherries, some had mangoes, some had chocolate chips, and some had a mix.

“Tell me, Matthew,” said Mr. Baker, “what fraction of the cake has chocolate chips AND mangoes, but NOT cherries?” (The mangoes are the orange pieces.)

feedback.html: Yes, that's right. Well done!

Oops, read the question carefully!

Mr. Baker is asking about the fraction of the cake that contains chocolate chips. The colour of the pieces does not matter! Try again.

Oops, it looks like you've forgotten what the parts of a fraction are.

Let's look at that again, and try to remember them!
No, that's not right. Let's take another look.

content.html:
“That was also a bit tricky, but you’re learning!” said Mr. Baker. “Let’s try one more.”

﻿

 

“Tell me, Matthew,” said Mr. Baker, “what fraction of the cake has chocolate chips?”

feedback.html: Correct! Let's try another.
No worries, let's go back one step and see what the numbers in the fraction tell us.
That's not right. Let's go back one step, and see what the numbers in the fraction tell us.

value: The number of equal parts that the whole cake is divided into.

content.html: "Great!" said Mr. Baker. “Now, here's another question for you. If I write the fraction 5/9, what does the '9' mean?”

feedback.html: Correct! Let's try another.
No, that's not right. Look again and count how many parts are shaded.

hint_content.html:
The cake is divided into seven equal parts. Each part is called a seventh.

How many sevenths are shaded? You can just count them.

content.html:
“Good, Matthew!” said Mr. Baker. “Let’s try another one.”

“Here’s a cake cut into seven equal parts, or sevenths. It’s important that the parts are all equal! How much of the cake is shaded?”

explanation.html:
The whole cake is divided into 12 equal pieces, so the denominator is 12.

5 of these pieces have mangoes and chocolate chips, but no cherries. So the numerator is 5.

Therefore, the answer is 5/12.

feedback.html: Yes, that's right. Well done, that was tricky!
Oops, read Mr. Baker's question carefully -- we're looking for the fraction of cake that has no cherries! Try again.
No, 12/12 is the number of pieces of cake which have chocolate chips. But that's not what Mr. Baker is asking for. Read the question and try again -- you can do this!
You've got the denominator right, but you haven't counted the number of pieces with mangoes correctly. Try again!
Oops, it looks like you've forgotten what the parts of a fraction are! Let's go and revise that, since it'll be useful later.
No, that's not right -- the denominator is wrong. Make sure you count the number of pieces of cake correctly!

hint_content.html: To do this question, you'll need to count very carefully. Double-check your work, and use a pencil and paper to take notes if you need to.
The denominator of the fraction is the total number of pieces of cake.
There are 12 pieces of cake, so the denominator is 12.

The numerator is trickier. We want to know what fraction of the cake "has chocolate chips AND mangoes, but NOT cherries”. 

So, we need to count the number of pieces that have chocolate chips and mangoes (the orange pieces), but not cherries. That would be the numerator.
Which pieces only have orange fruits and black dots, but no red fruits? There are exactly 5 of them. So the numerator is 5.

content.html:
“Let's try again, Matthew!” said Mr. Baker. He pointed again to the coconut cake.

“Matthew,” said Mr. Baker, “what fraction of the cake has chocolate chips AND mangoes, but NOT cherries?” (The mangoes are the orange pieces.)

feedback.html: Correct! You're ready for the next step.
No, that's not right. Let's learn that again!

No, that's not right. Let's try again to understand what the parts of a fraction mean.
No, that's not right. How many parts are shaded? And how many equal parts is the shape divided into?

content.html: “Correct! And what fraction is shown by the shaded part of this drawing?”

explanation.html:
The first number is the count of selected pieces, which is 1.

The second number is the count of all the pieces, which is 6.

So, the fraction is 1/6.

feedback.html: Correct! You're ready for the next question.
No, that's not right. Let's try again to understand what the parts of a fraction mean.
No, that's not right. How many parts are shaded? And how many equal parts is the whole shape divided into? You can do this!

hint_content.html:
You'll need to enter your answer as a number, then "/", then another number.

Example: if there are 2 shaded pieces, and 5 pieces in total, the fraction to type is 2/5.
The first part of the fraction is the number of selected pieces. In the picture, how many pieces are selected?
The second number is the total number of pieces. This always includes all the pieces, both the ones that are selected, and the ones that aren't selected.

content.html:
“Very good!" said Mr. Baker.

"Now, what fraction is shown by the shaded part of this drawing?”

content.html:
“Yes, indeed!" said Mr. Baker.

"Now, here’s a trickier one. Which of these pictures has a shaded part that represents the fraction 2/3?"

feedback.html: Correct! You are doing great.
That's right, but there are other correct answers, too. Keep looking!
No, that's not right. Maybe you forgot what a denominator is? Let's go back and take another look.
No, that's not right. Remember: the denominator is always the second or bottom number, the total number of pieces the whole is divided into.”

hint_content.html: It's possible to select more than one correct answer!

Remember what Mr. Baker said:

"The numerator is always the first or top number, the number of pieces we want. The denominator is always the second or bottom number, the total number of pieces the whole is divided into."

For example: in 5/6, the numerator is 5, and the denominator is 6.

Can you figure out the numerators and denominators for the given fractions? Write them all down first, then select the ones with denominator 3.

content.html:
“You’re doing great!" said Mr. Baker. "As you can see, it doesn’t matter if the numerator is larger or smaller than the denominator. It’s always the number that comes first!

“Now, look at these cakes, all cut into pieces. Which of the fractions shown have a denominator of 3? There might be more than one.”

feedback.html: Correct! Keep it up!

No, that's not right. It doesn't matter which of the numbers is bigger. All that matters is which number comes first or second. 

Let's look again at the definition!

content.html:
“Very good!" said Mr. Baker.

"Now, what is the numerator of the fraction 9/5?”

"Let's make sure you know how to write a fraction, Matthew," said Mr. Baker. "Take your time to understand this carefully, and don't rush, otherwise we'll need to keep looking at this again."

"Now, remember," said Mr. Baker, "when writing a fraction, we need to count two things. First, we write the number of parts we want. Then, we write the total number of parts. Take a look at these examples, and make sure you understand how the fractions relate to the images before continuing."

"When you're ready, let's try again!"

feedback.html: Correct! You're doing great.
No, that's not right. Look at the definition and try again.

content.html:
"Now," said Mr. Baker, "to properly talk about fractions, there are two words you need to know: numerator and denominator.

"The numerator is always the first or top number, the number of pieces we want. The denominator is always the second or bottom number, the total number of pieces the whole is divided into. For example, in 1/6, the numerator is 1, and the denominator is 6."

“Here's a question for you. In 2/8, what is the denominator?”

title: Fractions 1 - What is a Fraction?
objective: Join Matthew as he learns what a fraction is.
